title: If Statements and Conditions
description: Learn how to make decisions in your programs using if statements

content.introduction:
Programs need to make decisions based on different conditions. The `if` statement is the most fundamental control flow structure that allows your program to execute different code based on whether a condition is true or false.

In this lesson, you'll learn how to use if statements to create programs that respond intelligently to different situations.

### What You'll Learn
- Basic if statements
- if-else statements
- if-else-if chains
- Nested if statements
- Combining conditions

concepts.title: Basic If Statement
concepts.description: Executes code only if a condition is true: if condition then statement

concepts.title: If-Else Statement
concepts.description: Executes one block if true, another if false: if condition then statement1 else statement2

concepts.title: If-Else-If Chains
concepts.description: Check multiple conditions in sequence, executing the first one that's true

concepts.title: Begin-End Blocks
concepts.description: Use begin-end to execute multiple statements in an if branch

examples.title: Simple If Statement
examples.description: Check a single condition and execute code if true
examples.expectedOutput:
You are an adult.
Program finished.

examples.title: If-Else Statement
examples.description: Execute one block if true, another if false

examples.title: If-Else-If Chain
examples.code:
program GradeChecker;

var
  score: Integer;

begin
  score := 85;
  
  if score >= 90 then
    WriteLn('Grade: A - Excellent!')
  else if score >= 80 then
    WriteLn('Grade: B - Good job!')
  else if score >= 70 then
    WriteLn('Grade: C - Fair')
  else if score >= 60 then
    WriteLn('Grade: D - Needs improvement')
  else
    WriteLn('Grade: F - Failed');
end.

exercises.title: Even or Odd Checker
exercises.description: Write a program that checks if a number is even or odd. Use the modulus operator (mod) to check if a number is divisible by 2.
hints: Use the mod operator: number mod 2
If number mod 2 = 0, the number is even

exercises.title: Temperature Warning System
exercises.description: Create a program that displays different messages based on temperature: Below 0: 'Freezing!', 0-15: 'Cold', 16-25: 'Comfortable', Above 25: 'Hot'
exercises.solution:
program TempWarning;

var
  temp: Integer;

begin
  temp := 18;
  
  if temp < 0 then
    WriteLn('Freezing!')
  else if temp <= 15 then
    WriteLn('Cold')
  else if temp <= 25 then
    WriteLn('Comfortable')
  else
    WriteLn('Hot');
end.
hints: Check conditions in order from lowest to highest
The else clause handles anything above 25

exercises.title: Login Validator
exercises.description: Write a program that checks if both username is 'admin' AND password is 'secret123'. Display 'Login successful' if both are correct, otherwise 'Login failed'.
hints: Use the 'and' operator to combine two conditions
Both must be true for login to succeed
Use parentheses around each condition for clarity

exercises.title: Leap Year Checker
exercises.description: A year is a leap year if: it's divisible by 4 AND (not divisible by 100 OR divisible by 400). Write a program to check if a year is a leap year.
hints: Combine with: (div by 4) AND ((not div by 100) OR (div by 400))
You can store the result in a boolean variable first

content.summary:
Great work! You've mastered:

- **Basic if statements**: Execute code conditionally
- **If-else statements**: Choose between two alternatives
- **If-else-if chains**: Handle multiple conditions
- **Begin-end blocks**: Execute multiple statements in a branch
- **Nested if statements**: If statements inside if statements
- **Combined conditions**: Using and, or, not operators

If statements are the foundation of program logic and decision-making!
content.nextSteps: Next, you'll learn about **case statements** - a cleaner way to handle multiple specific values. Case statements are perfect when you need to check a variable against many different values!
